text: well certainly science and religion are
the two big ones that come to mind and I
think unfortunately pulling us in
opposite directions I mean for me the
large story that has been playing out
for several centuries and that continues
to play out today on the world stage is
the battle between the rational and the
irrational for me science represents one
of these religion I'm afraid represents
the other so I think it would be hard to
tell the story of human uh civilization
without talking about science and
religion very easy to tell most of the
story by talking only about these two
things certainly signal events in both
science and religion as a scientist one
can point to Darwin one can point to
Einstein I don't think single events are
what either of these forces are about I
think these these two things are ways of
thinking it's not about the discoveries
that science has produced because as I
always tell my students half of what I'm
going to teach you today is wrong I just
don't know which half yet you know
science is about constantly revising our
beliefs so I wouldn't point to single
discoveries and say wasn't this
important what science really has to
teach us is a way of knowing it's a way
of finding out what the truth is about
the world uh science is not infallible
but it's as close as we can get you know
Winston Churchill I believe it was who
said um democracy is the worst form of
government except for all the others
well science is the worst way of knowing
except for all the other ways of knowing
